facts.text: A decree was passed against Narasimhaswamy and his four sons in Small Cause Suit No. 9 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In a certain money suit, being Small Cause Suit No. 9 of 1953. a decree had been passed against Narasimhaswamy and his four sons who were members of a Mitakshara Hindu joint family.

facts.text: Shares of the four sons in joint family properties (4/5th share) were auctioned on December 21, 1936 and purchased by Sivayya.

anchor.surface_text: In execution of that decree the shares of the four sons in the joint family properties, described altogether as 4/5th share, were put up to auction on December 21, 1936 and purchased by one Sivayya whose successors-in-interest are the appellants.

facts.text: Narasimhaswamy's share was not put up for sale because an application for his adjudication as insolvent was pending.

anchor.surface_text: The father Narasimhaswamys share had number been put up for sale because an application fo.r his adjudication as insolvent was then pending.

facts.text: The sale to Sivayya was confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: The sale to Sivayya was duly companyfirmed.

facts.text: Sivayya sold the properties to Prakasalingam.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Sivayya sold the properties purchased by him at the auction to one Prakasalingam.

facts.text: On November 6, 1939, order under O. 21, rr. 35 and 96 CPC for delivery of joint possession to Prakasalingam.

anchor.surface_text: On November 6, 1939, an order was made. under O. 21, rr. 35 2  and 96 of the Code of Civil Procedure for delivery of joint possession of the properties purchased to Prakasalingam along with the members of the joint family in actual possession.

facts.text: Possession was delivered to Prakasalingam symbolically by beat of drum.

anchor.surface_text: This order was duly carried out and possession was delivered to Prakasalingam by publishing that fact by beat of drum as prescribed in these rules.

facts.text: Prakasalingam re-transferred the properties to Sivayya.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, Prakasalingam re- transferred the properties to Sivayya.

facts.text: Sivayya filed suit on October 16, 1951 for partition and possession of 4/5th share.

anchor.surface_text: On October 16, 1951, Sivayya filed the. suit out of which this appeal arises, against the then members of the joint family whose Sup/65 12 number had by that time increased, and various other persons holding as alienees from them, asking for a partition of the joint family properties into five equal shares and thereafter for possession of four of such shares by removing the defendants from possession.

facts.text: Trial Court decreed the suit for 2/3rd share, not 4/5th, due to birth of 5th son.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court decreed the suit but held that Sivayya was number entitled to a 4/5th share but only to a 2/3rd share because before the decree a 5th son had been bom to Narasimliaswamy who had number been made a party to the suit or the execution proceedings and whose share had number companysequently passed under the auction sale.

facts.text: High Court of Andhra Pradesh allowed appeal on ground suit barred by limitation under Art. 144 Limitation Act, dismissed cross-objection.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the defendants appealed to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh from this judgment. The High Court allowed the appeal on the ground that the suit was barred by limitation under Art. 144 of Schedule 1 to the Limitation Act.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court: Civil Appeal No. 420 of 1963 from Andhra Pradesh High Court judgment dated September 9, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 420 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 9. 1960 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 300 of 1955.

facts.text: A 5th son was born to Narasimhaswamy before the auction sale.

anchor.surface_text: because before the decree a 5th son had been bom to Narasimliaswamy who had number been made a party to the suit or the execution proceedings

facts.text: Supreme Court held suit not barred by limitation under Art. 144 or 120.

anchor.surface_text: We companysider it unnecessary to decide in this ,case which of the two articles applies for in our view, the suit was number barred under either.

facts.text: Symbolic possession on Nov 6, 1939 interrupted adverse possession.

anchor.surface_text: By the delivery of symbolical possession under the order of November 6, 1939, the adverse possession of the, defendants was interrupted.

facts.text: Sivayya died pending High Court appeal; appellants are successors-in-interest.

anchor.surface_text: Sivayya having died pending the appeal in the High Court, the appellants as his successors- in-interest, have companye up to this Court in further appeal under Art. 133 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Sale confirmed on February 23, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: The sale was companyfirmed on February 23, 1937.

facts.text: Sivayya sold to Prakasalingam on March 5, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: Later on i.e., on March 5, 1939 the purchaser Sivayya sold the right he had purchased to one Prakasalingam

facts.text: Reconveyance from Prakasalingam to Sivayya on April 11, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Sivayya obtained a reconveyable of the right from Prakasalingam on April 11, 1945.

facts.text: Trial court gave decree for 2/3rds share of properties in Sch. A.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt accordingly gave a decree for partition and separate possession to the plaintiff of 2/3rds share of the properties mentioned in Sch. A of the plaint.

facts.text: 6th defendant born before court sale, not impleaded.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed by the plaintiff that the 6th defendant was born before the Court sale and it is also number disputed that the execution case was taken out only against defendants 2 to 5.

facts.text: Supreme Court restored trial court decree, dismissed cross-objection.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we would allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court except as to the dismissal of the cross-objection and restore that of the learned trial Judge.
under Art. 133 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the suit was barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: They are, whether the suit was barred by limitation and whether Sivayya was entitled to a 4/5th share.

issues.text: whether Sivayya was entitled to a 4/5th share

anchor.surface_text: They are, whether the suit was barred by limitation and whether Sivayya was entitled to a 4/5th share. On the question of limitation, two articles of the Act were pressed for our consideration as applicable to the case.

issues.text: which of the two articles [144 and 120] applies

anchor.surface_text: They are Arts. 144 and 120. We consider it unnecessary to decide in this case which of the two articles applies for in our view, the suit was not barred under either.

issues.text: whether the delivery of symbolical possession under the order of November 6, 1939 interrupted the adverse possession of the defendants

anchor.surface_text: By the delivery of symbolical possession under the order of November 6, 1939, the adverse possession of the defendants was interrupted. Time has, therefore, to commence to run from that date

holdings.text: The suit was not barred by limitation under either Article 144 or Article 120 of the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: We consider it unnecessary to decide in this ,case which of the two articles applies for in our view, the suit was not barred under either.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Symbolic possession on November 6, 1939 interrupted adverse possession under Art. 144; no infringement threat under Art. 120, right to sue did not accrue earlier.

holdings.text: Delivery of symbolical possession under the order of November 6, 1939 interrupted the adverse possession of the defendants.

anchor.surface_text: By the delivery of symbolical possession under the order of November 6, 1939, the adverse possession of the, defendants was interrupted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual interruption occurred regardless of order's legality; possession obtained by beat of drum as per O.21 rr.35 & 96.

holdings.text: The order for delivery of possession was not a nullity despite being erroneous in law.

anchor.surface_text: We agree that the order cannot be supported in law but we do not see that it was for this reason a nullity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court acted within jurisdiction, though wrong in law; order effective unless set aside; distinguished cases on lack of jurisdiction.

holdings.text: O. 21 r. 35 applies to the order for joint possession via s. 36 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: This contention cannot be accepted because under s. 36 of the Code the provisions relating to the execution of decrees are applicable to execution of orders.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.36 CPC extends decree execution rules to orders; order also fits O.21 r.96.

holdings.text: Sivayya was not entitled to a 4/5th share but only to 2/3rd share.

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts below have held that what Sivayya purchased at the auction sale was the share of the four sons of Narasimhaswamy in the joint family properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 5th son (Venugopal) born before sale, not impleaded in suit or execution; his 1/6th share not proceeded against or sold.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to decide whether Art. 144 or 120 applies as suit not barred under either.

anchor.surface_text: We consider it unnecessary to decide in this case which of the two articles applies for in our view, the suit was not barred under either.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumed Art.144 applies but suit within time; expressed doubts on Art.144 applicability to alienee's suit pre-partition.

holdings.text: A suit by alienee of coparcener's undivided share for general partition is governed by Article 144 Limitation Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit seeks possession of allotted share post-partition; adverse possession of non-alienors starts from purchase date.

holdings.text: Symbolic delivery of possession interrupts adverse possession even if order illegal, as court had jurisdiction.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Executing court had jurisdiction; symbolic delivery tantamount to actual possession, breaks continuity per precedent.
